definition: Sudden and unexpected; speaking or acting in a short, sharp way.
examples: The car came to an abrupt stop.
His abrupt reply ended the conversation.

extra.memory_tip: Abrupt = a break that happens ‘ab-rupt’—right now.

definition: To successfully reach a goal by effort or skill.
examples: She achieved her target score.
Teams achieve more when they plan.

extra.memory_tip: Achieve = a goal you ‘chiefly’ aim for.

definition: To try to do something difficult; the act of trying.
examples: We attempted the hardest question first. (verb)
Her second attempt was successful. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Attempt = put your effort ‘at’ the task.

definition: A strong feeling of dislike or lack of respect for someone or something.
examples: He spoke with open contempt for cheating.
The rule-breaker faced contempt from the group.

extra.memory_tip: Contempt = you ‘can’t attempt’ to respect it.

definition: To amuse or interest; to consider an idea.
examples: The magician entertained the crowd.
We entertained the idea of a class trip.

definition: A quick, brief look; to see something for a very short time.
examples: I caught a glimpse of the comet. (noun)
We glimpsed dolphins near the boat. (verb)

definition: To make fun of; not real but made to be similar; a practice version.
examples: It’s unkind to mock someone’s accent. (verb)
We sat a mock exam before the real one. (adjective)

extra.memory_tip: Mock = mimic with meanness—or a model run.

definition: To keep doing something even when it is difficult or others want you to stop.
examples: She persisted until the puzzle was solved.
Rain persisted all weekend.

definition: To cause someone to do or believe something by giving reasons.
examples: He persuaded his friend to join the club.
A good argument can persuade the reader.

extra.memory_tip: Persuade = put ‘sweet’ sense into someone’s mind.

definition: A distinct stage in a process; to carry out or introduce in stages.
examples: The moon has different phases. (noun)
They will phase the changes over a year. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Phase = a face of time in a longer cycle.

definition: Attractively old-fashioned or unusual in a pleasing way.
examples: We stayed in a quaint cottage by the sea.
The village has quaint narrow streets.

definition: To remember; to order a product or person to return; the act of remembering or calling back.
examples: I can’t recall where I put the keys. (verb)
The company issued a recall of the toys. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Re-call = call it back to mind or place.

definition: To refuse to accept or agree to; a person or thing that is not accepted.
examples: The editor rejected the article. (verb)
Factory rejects are sold at a discount. (noun)

definition: To change something to improve it; in UK English, to study again for an exam.
examples: Please revise your paragraph for clarity.
I’m revising for science tonight.

extra.memory_tip: Revise = re-vision—see it again and improve.

definition: Quick to feel or notice; easily upset; needing careful handling.
examples: Her skin is sensitive to sunlight.
Be careful—this is sensitive information.
